children: Radiograph showing advanced rheumatoid arthritis in the hand. Shown are ulnar deviation at the metacarpophalangeal joints; marginal erosions most prominently at the second through fifth metacarpophalangeal joints and the second and third proximal interphalangeal joints (
); and joint-space narrowing at the wrist, metacarpophalangeal, and proximal interphalangeal joints and within the carpus, which also represents erosive disease. Note the loss of the ulnar styloid (
), another common sign of bony erosion in rheumatoid arthritis.
